articles.headline: Goodbye to the Wild Wild Web
articles.snippet: The internet is changing, and the freewheeling, anything-goes culture of social media is being replaced by something more accountable.
articles.abstract: The internet is changing, and the freewheeling, anything-goes culture of social media is being replaced by something more accountable.
articles.lead_paragraph: It felt like a dam breaking, or the changing of a guard.

articles.headline: Why June Was Such a Terrible Month for Trump
articles.snippet: Last month represented the political nadir of President Trump’s three and a half years in office, thanks to self-inflicted wounds as he played to his base and missteps by a fractured campaign.
articles.abstract: Last month represented the political nadir of President Trump’s three and a half years in office, thanks to self-inflicted wounds as he played to his base and missteps by a fractured campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last Saturday night, over dinner at the White House, Bernard Marcus, a top Republican donor, told President Trump he was alarmed at Mr. Trump’s plummeting poll numbers and Jared Kushner’s stewardship of his father-in-law’s re-election effort.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Hedge Fund’s Run at Tribune Publishing Ends With a New Board Seat
articles.snippet: Journalists have been wary of Alden Global Capital, which is known for gutting newsrooms to eke out profits from struggling publications.
articles.abstract: Journalists have been wary of Alden Global Capital, which is known for gutting newsrooms to eke out profits from struggling publications.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alden Global Capital seemed in position this week to take control of Tribune Publishing, a move that would have enabled the New York hedge fund to merge the parent company of The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun with MediaNews Group, an Alden-owned newspaper chain, to create a new media giant.

articles.headline: Colleges Face Rising Revolt by Professors
articles.snippet: Most universities plan to bring students back to campus. But many of their teachers are concerned about joining them.
articles.abstract: Most universities plan to bring students back to campus. But many of their teachers are concerned about joining them.
articles.lead_paragraph: College students across the country have been warned that campus life will look drastically different in the fall, with temperature checks at academic buildings, masks in half-empty lecture halls and maybe no football games.

articles.headline: The #Vanlife Business Is Booming
articles.snippet: Coronavirus is just a distant memory while zipping around in a several-hundred-thousand-dollar custom van on the open road.
articles.abstract: Coronavirus is just a distant memory while zipping around in a several-hundred-thousand-dollar custom van on the open road.
articles.lead_paragraph: I do not own a car or a house or even a bicycle. Nor am I prone to following Instagram trends. Yet for weeks I have had an obsession: getting rid of all my possessions, breaking the apartment lease, and moving with my dog and my girlfriend into a tricked-out van.

articles.headline: Symone Sanders Bet on Biden, and Herself
articles.snippet: No one is telling her to wait her turn now.
articles.abstract: No one is telling her to wait her turn now.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Growing up in Omaha, Symone Sanders would sometimes assume the identity of an alter-ego character named “Donna Burns,” an imaginary TV personality who would repurpose hairbrushes or forks or pens (or whatever) to use as her microphone.

articles.headline: Latinos Back Black Lives Matter Protests. They Want Change for Themselves, Too.
articles.snippet: Many Latinos are pushing for an acknowledgment of the systemic racism they face, and a conversation about over-policing in their own communities.
articles.abstract: Many Latinos are pushing for an acknowledgment of the systemic racism they face, and a conversation about over-policing in their own communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — “Tu lucha es mi lucha,” several signs declared at a recent Black Lives Matter protest near the Arizona State Capitol. Your struggle is my struggle. The sea of faces included young Latinos who had marched before, during the immigrant rights movement in the state a decade ago, when Joe Arpaio championed draconian policies as the sheriff of Maricopa County. There was no doubt in these protesters’ minds: Their fights against racism are bound up together.

articles.headline: What Hong Kong’s Pandemic Experience Taught Uber About Other Cities
articles.snippet: The city was among the first to close and among the first to reopen. But Uber’s lessons there could be difficult to duplicate elsewhere.
articles.abstract: The city was among the first to close and among the first to reopen. But Uber’s lessons there could be difficult to duplicate elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — In late February, Uber executives were set to gather in San Francisco to form business plans for the year as the coronavirus steadily spread beyond China. While some executives who were initially invited had been told to stay home, the remaining few huddled at Uber’s headquarters to make plans for the inevitable pandemic.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Tiffany May

articles.headline: For Maine Lobstermen, a Perfect Storm Threatens the Summer Season
articles.snippet: The state’s lobster industry, already struggling before the virus, could be crippled as tourism dries up, leaving boatloads of crustaceans and no one to eat them.
articles.abstract: The state’s lobster industry, already struggling before the virus, could be crippled as tourism dries up, leaving boatloads of crustaceans and no one to eat them.
articles.lead_paragraph: OFF THE COAST OF MAINE — As he pulled alongside one of his lobster pots, marked by a red and yellow buoy on the Penobscot Bay, Mike Hutchings extracted and measured several of the crustaceans that would contribute to his 130-pound catch that day. It was a decent haul but his assessment of the fishing season was grim: “The worst it’s ever been.”
